answer:
Frame‐by‐frame analysis:

• Frame 1:  
  – Right side: A large RV is clearly visible up ahead. Behind it (closer to the camera), there appears to be a yellow sedan, then a dark SUV. At the very right edge (roughly near the corner), there is a bulky truck‐type vehicle with a bed or container in the rear (not yet clearly visible).  
  – No bicycle is apparent.  

• Frame 2:  
  – The RV is still farther up the block on the right. The yellow car and dark SUV remain between the RV and the camera. That same tall‐sided truck toward the near right edge is becoming a bit clearer, though still obscured by darkness and weather.  

• Frame 3:  
  – RV remains ahead on the right. The yellow car and SUV are still behind it (i.e., closer to the camera than the RV). The truck’s shape is more discernible, showing a large, squared‐off cargo area.  

• Frame 4:  
  – The camera has progressed; the RV is now noticeably farther away compared to that truck on the right edge, which is quite close in the foreground. Still no bicycle or minivan visible on the right side.  

• Frame 5:  
  – Closest to the camera on the right side is what looks like a short‐bed or dump‐style cargo truck (large open container on back)—consistent with a “construction truck.”  
  – The RV is farther up the block. The yellow car and SUV are also ahead of the truck from the camera’s perspective.  
  – No bicycle is visible, and a minivan only appears on the left side of the street.  

Contextual reasoning and matching to choices:  
• The largest, boxy, open‐bed vehicle nearest the camera on the right cannot be an RV or a minivan.  
• No bicycle is present on the right side of the roadway.  
• By appearance and proximity, the bulky open‐bed vehicle is best identified as the “construction truck.”  

Therefore, the vehicle on the right side of the road that is closest to ego is the construction truck.

<answer>A</answer>
